Award.AwardTitle: In Touch with Molecules: Extending Learning with Cyber-enabled Tangibles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose this project is to examine the capabilities of cyber-enabled tangible tools in real educational settings with five teachers (three high schools and two college) and 450 high school and college students. The project evaluates the use of cyber-enabled tangible tools to enhance student's understanding of three difficult topics in molecular biology: (1) protein structure, (2) DNA, and (3) viruses. As core concepts of molecular biology instruction in the U.S., students often have difficulties understanding how molecular interactions result in structures that give rise to function. The intent of this project is to help students understand mappings between structure, function, and emergent properties and processes. Hence, the cyber-enabled tangible tools will test whether technology enhances and improves how difficult subject matter is taught. Additionally, the study provides information about what areas of content can be effectively conveyed with these technologies and for which levels of students (high school or college).

The broader impact of the project are potentially transformative improvements in medicine, pharmacology, agriculture, ecology education. The tools promote computer-human interactions at the atomic, molecular, and organ levels.

Hand-held objects with markers, similar to barcodes, use a web cam to track and illustrate different properties and features on a computer screen. Research shows that as molecular biology grows in prominence, there is greater need for materials and scaffolds that promote deep learning and motivation. To help meet those needs, the project brings together leaders from top research entities, researchers in cognition and student learning, scientists, science educators, teachers, and high school and college students to investigate how cyber-enabled tangibles promote different and improved ways to learn core concepts in molecular biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The In Touch with Molecules project leveraged advances in scientific understanding of molecular structures and 3D printing technology by bringing scientifically accurate, functional models of complex molecules (such as viral capsids, DNA, and enzymes) into classrooms.

Molecular biology addresses how interactions between molecules give rise to complex biological phenomena. As innovation in the field has far-reaching implications for medicine, pharmacology, agriculture, ecology and other disciplines, there is a growing need for effective educational materials and methods that provide scaffolding for molecular science.

Our project built on the groundbreaking work of Dr. Arthur Olson, director of the Molecular Graphics Lab at The Scripps Research Institute, who has developed novel approaches to producing tangible models of complex molecules. Understanding molecular processes requires learning about concepts such as energy and forces that cannot be seen and are challenging to convey through images or text. However, as forces can be “felt,” novel, tangible models that invoke the tactile sense may more readily convey concepts such as stability (resulting from low potential energy states), kinetic energy (energy of motion of particles), and chemical attraction (through bonds or electrostatic potential).

Through an iterative research and development process, the In Touch with Molecules project refined models and classroom activities to promote different and improved ways of learning molecular biology content such as self-assembly, DNA replication, and protein folding. Engaging with the models enabled students to feel the stability that emerges as a strand of protein folds into a superhelix, experience the kinetic energy of the cellular environment by shaking a viral capsid model, and explore how the configuration and attraction between hydrogen bonds (represented by magnets) enables the bases of DNA to pair, or occasionally mis-pair.

Our research suggests the models and accompanying materials were usable and feasible for use in current instructional practice, and students and teachers found the models engaging and informative. Findings from pilot tests indicate the unique tangible models provided students with new ways of thinking about structure and function and have much promise for building deeper understanding of core concepts such as self assembly, DNA replication, chirality, structural stability, and emergent properties. The models engage tactile senses and cognitive processes that go beyond the visual and bring a sense of reality and natural interaction into the process of exploration and understanding. Current and future advances of both 3D printing and the use of mixed or augmented reality will provide new ways for students to experience and learn about the unseen world of molecular biology.
